review.title: Gendered Conversation in a Social Game-Streaming Platform
review.abstract: Online social media and games are increasingly replacing offline social activities. Social media is now an indispensable mode of communication; online gaming is not only a genuine social activity but also a popular spectator sport. With support for anonymity and larger audiences, online interaction shrinks social and geographical barriers. Despite such benefits, social disparities such as gender inequality persist in online social media. In particular, online gaming communities have been criticized for persistent gender disparities and objectification. As gaming evolves into a social platform, persistence of gender disparity is a pressing question. Yet, there are few large-scale, systematic studies of gender inequality and objectification in social gaming platforms. Here we analyze more than one billion chat messages from Twitch, a social game-streaming platform, to study how the gender of streamers is associated with the nature of conversation. Using a combination of computational text analysis methods, we show that gendered conversation and objectification is prevalent in chats. Female streamers receive significantly more objectifying comments while male streamers receive more game-related comments. This difference is more pronounced for popular streamers. There also exists a large number of users who post only on female or male streams. Employing a neural vector-space embedding (paragraph vector) method, we analyze gendered chat messages and create prediction models that (i) identify the gender of streamers based on messages posted in the channel and (ii) identify the gender a viewer prefers to watch based on their chat messages. Our findings suggest that disparities in social game-streaming platforms is a nuanced phenomenon that involves the gender of streamers as well as those who produce gendered and game-related conversation.

metadata.title: Gendered Conversation in a Social Game-Streaming Platform

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: In fact, most people who are able to survive themselves are not able to survive themselves; they are also able to survive themselves; they are not the ones who are able to survive themselves; they are not the ones who are able to survive themselves, and they are not the ones who are able to survive themselves.

sections.heading: 1.1 Ethics Statement
sections.text: This study was reviewed by the IRB of Indiana University Bloomington ("Gender Objectification in Online Conversations," Protocol # 1609276630).

sections.heading: 2. DATA AND METHODS
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1 Data and Terminology
sections.text: Our data includes all chat messages posted in public Twitch chat rooms between August 26 and November 10, 2014. There were 1,275,396,751 messages posted on 927,247 channels (1375 messages per channel on average), out of 6,716,014 viewers (190 messages per user on average). For each message, the following information is available: timestamp, author, channel and text. Author and channel are identified by screen name; for the channel this is the screen name of the streamer. Similar to other social media, the activity and popularity of Twitch channels are highly distorted. We can quantify them by the number of messages produced by each user and channel, as well as the number of users chatting on a channel (for popularity).

sections.heading: 2.2 Statistically Overrepresented Words
sections.text: As our first exploratory analysis, we find that unigrams and bigrams are over-represented in male or female streamers, using log odds ratios using the informative dirichlet method [26], which estimates the log odds ratio of each word w between two corpora i and j taking into account the previous frequencies obtained from a background corpus α. The log odds ratio for word w, δ (i-j) w = log (yiw + α0 − (yiw + αw)) + − log (yyyw + αw + αwni − (yyyw + αw)))))), (1) where ni (resp. nj) is the size of the corpus i (resp. j), yiw (resp. yyyw) the number of words w in corpus i (resp. j), αw the size of the corpus i (resp. nj) the size of the corpus i (resp. jw) or the number of words (resp. jw) (jp).

sections.heading: 2.3 Word and Document Embeddings
sections.text: To characterize individual users and channels, we create a document for each channel (and user) by aggregating each chat message in the channel (by the user), and then collectively obtain vector space representations of words, users and channels using the paragraph vector (doc2vec) method [28], which is an extension of the popular word2vec embedding method [29]. This common embedding not only allows us to perform vector operations between documents and words, but it has been argued that it outperforms other embedding methods in document similarity tasks [30]. We use the Skip-gram model with negative sampling (SGNS) to learn word vectors. Among two main doc2vec models - distributed memory (DM) and distributed bag of words (DBOW) - we use the DGNS model for its reported simplicity and simplicity of concepts.

sections.heading: 3. RESULTS
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Exploratory Language Analysis
sections.text: We group channels based on their popularity (i.e., popular versus less popular) and gender, and produce four "documents": "popular male," "popular female," "less popular male" and "less popular female." To remove channel-specific terms, we retain only words used in at least 100 channels, 20 female channels and 20 male channels. We make two comparisons: popular female versus popular male and less popular male. We calculate log-odds-ratio-ratio-ratio-ratio-ratio-ratio-ratio-ratio-ratio-ratio-ratio-ratio-ratio-ratio-ratio-ratio-ratio-ratio-ratio (see § 2.2) for unigrams and bigrams by using the previous Twiquency in the entire dataset.

sections.heading: 3.2 Analyzing Channels
sections.text: To identify non-trivial gender terms, we first remove trivial terms that signal gender: "he," "she," "hes," "be," "her," "he," "hers," "herself," "man," "woman," "man," "woman," "man," "man," "woman," "man," "woman," "man," "man," "woman," "man," "man," "woman," "woman." After pre-processing, we train the doc2vec model (see Sec.).

sections.heading: 3.3 Analyzing Individual Users
sections.text: We wonder whether viewers and their chat messages are also gender-specific, by examining the gender preferences in users "channels and hiding their linguistic differences. We examine whether the selection of channels is led to a certain gender by determining the proportion of female channels in the channels themselves. We narrow down to 93,898 (5%) active users who have posted at least 100 messages, primarily in order to receive re- (a) recentage of female channels in channels posted on at least 5 channels.

sections.heading: 4. DISCUSSION
sections.text: In fact, most people who are able to survive on their own are not able to survive on their own.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: We thank Cyrus Hall, Spencer Nelson and Drew Harry for accessing the Twitch chat log data.

referenceMentions.context: Simone de Beauvoir said, “One is not born a woman, but becomes one” [1], highlighting the situation of women as not free to make decisions about their life, but rather shackled by a society that objectifies them, severely limiting their actions and opportunities.
Such media continue to reinforce women as objects under the “gaze” of men [3].
For instance, in the popular microblogging platform Twitter, the “glass-ceiling” effect [4] and genderbiased user dialogue [5, 6] are observed.
For instance, in the popular microblogging platform Twitter, the “glass-ceiling” effect [4] and genderbiased user dialogue [5, 6] are observed.
For instance, in the popular microblogging platform Twitter, the “glass-ceiling” effect [4] and genderbiased user dialogue [5, 6] are observed.
Studies on image search engines [7] and Wikipedia [8, 9, 10] also demonstrate persistent gender stereotypes and disparities.
Studies on image search engines [7] and Wikipedia [8, 9, 10] also demonstrate persistent gender stereotypes and disparities.
Studies on image search engines [7] and Wikipedia [8, 9, 10] also demonstrate persistent gender stereotypes and disparities.

While data-driven research on online gender inequality has focused on several popular online platforms, online gaming has received little attention, although the advent of the Internet and of social media has transformed video games into genuine social activities [11].
Traditionally considered a “boy’s activity” [12, 13], the culture of gaming communities has been accused of misogyny [14].
Traditionally considered a “boy’s activity” [12, 13], the culture of gaming communities has been accused of misogyny [14].
Videos games themselves can be a medium that glorifies the objectification of women [15, 16, 17].
Videos games themselves can be a medium that glorifies the objectification of women [15, 16, 17].
Videos games themselves can be a medium that glorifies the objectification of women [15, 16, 17].

The online space of video games provides no respite from these inequities; ethnographic studies have observed that, when female gamers have revealed their identities online, gamers cease speaking about game-related topics and instead shift to the gamer herself and her gender [13, 18].

In Twitch, the spectacle of gaming is not only watching the video game and streamers but also the actions of the viewers themselves [22].

These platforms have become a powerful and influential medium for new and young gamers alike, and this influence may have far-reaching consequences outside the domain of social media, for example by distorting beliefs about women in the real world [23].

To control for this potential source of bias we thus match male and female streamers by stratifying on the channel activity distribution [25].
To do so, we use log-odds ratios with informative Dirichlet prior method [26].

By leveraging the informative prior obtained from the background corpus, this method often outperforms other methods such as PMI (point-wise mutual information) or TFIDF, particularly in detecting significant differences of frequent words without over-emphasizing fluctuations of rare words [26, 27].

This joint embedding not only allows us to do vector operations across documents and words, but has been argued to outperform other document embedding methods in document similarity comparison tasks [30].

Among two main doc2vec models — distributed memory (DM) and distributed bag of words (DBOW) — here we use the DBOW model because of its conceptual simplicity, efficiency, and reported superiority in performance [30].
We use the doc2vec implementation available in popular gensim Python library [31].
By objectifying cues, we mean language that reduce women to their body or appearance [32] or as objects to be owned or used [33].

If part of feminism’s remit [39] is to consider how society, females included, may play a role in constructing what a legitimate female’s identity is in, for example, online spaces, we argue that we should investigate how Twitch supports heteronormative stereotypes.

Our findings suggest that disparities in social game-streaming platforms is a nuanced phenomenon that involves the gender of streamers as well as those who produce gendered and game-related conversation.
